bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 125 (Monday, July 13, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BRENDAN F. BOYLE of Pennsylvania:H.R. 7578.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution under theGeneral Welfare Clause.[Page H3083]

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on the Budget, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

item.name: Government ethics and transparency, public corruption
Presidents and presidential powers, Vice Presidents

summary.text:
Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman Congressional Gold Medal Act

This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the award of a Congressional Gold Medal to Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman in recognition of his service to the United States and his courage to testify in the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump.

bill.title: Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.title: Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman Congressional Gold Medal Act

To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, in recognition of his service to the United States and his courage to testify in the impeachment inquiry of President Donald J. Trump.
Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman Congressional Gold Medal Act

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
